channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Hurricane Laura Strengthens to Near Category 5: Live Updates
item.description: The hurricane, now with 150 mile-per-hour winds, is projected to make landfall late Wednesday or early Thursday near the Texas-Louisiana border.
item.media:credit: William Widmer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents gathered at the Burton Complex, an event center in Lake Charles, La., for assistance with evacuation.

item.title: Kenosha Shootings: Two Killed and One Injured in Chaotic Night
item.description: Protesters have poured into the Wisconsin city’s streets after the shooting of Jacob Blake, a Black father who was partially paralyzed after a white officer fired at him in front of his children.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman and Sarah Mervosh
item.media:description: Aftermath following unrest in Kenosha, Wis., after the police shooting of Jacob Blake, a Black resident.

item.title: New Virus Hot Spots: U.S. Islands from Hawaii to Puerto Rico
item.description: U.S. islands in the Caribbean and the Pacific have growing cases of the coronavirus, which can spike even in places far removed from urban centers when controls are relaxed.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A banner in San Juan, P.R., asks visitors to keep noise down, wear a mask and throw garbage in bins.

item.title: Jerry Falwell Jr.’s Departure Brings Relief on Liberty University’s Campus
item.description: “We almost had a monarchy,” said one of many students who said they supported Mr. Falwell’s exit.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Graham
item.media:description: Jerry Falwell Jr. resigned from his position as president of Liberty University on Tuesday. He suggested he was happy to move on.

item.title: Forecasters Issue Dire Warnings for Hurricane Laura
item.description: Winds of about 150 miles per hour and a storm surge that meteorologists are calling “unsurvivable” are expected to barrage the Louisiana and Texas coasts as it makes landfall.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas, Chelsea Brasted and Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
item.media:credit: William Widmer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Evacuees get their temperature taken at the Burton Complex, an event center in Lake Charles, La.

item.title: How Chaos in Kenosha Is Already Swaying Some Voters in Wisconsin
item.description: As residents see fires and looting, some worry that local Democratic leaders are failing to keep control of the situation.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise and Ellen Almer Durston
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: A worker prepared to cover the windows of a damaged business in Kenosha, Wis., on Tuesday. The shooting of an unarmed Black man by the city’s police led to protests.

item.title: DNA Evidence Exonerates Man in 1983 Rape and Killing, Prosecutors Say
item.description: Prosecutors in Hillsborough County, Fla., said Robert DuBoise, 55, had been wrongfully convicted. On Wednesday, they moved to free him after he spent 37 years behind bars.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson

item.title: Live Updates: Jacob Blake Had Knife at Time of Police Shooting, Officials Say
item.description: Wisconsin’s attorney general also identified the Kenosha officer who shot Mr. Blake multiple times as Rusten Sheskey, a seven-year veteran.
item.media:description: Wisconsin Attorney General Josh Kaul during a news conference about the police shooting of Jacob Blake, a Black man, in Kenosha, Wis., on Wednesday.

item.title: Sailor Investigated for Arson in U.S.S. Bonhomme Richard Fire
item.description: It took four days to extinguish the July fire on the U.S.S. Bonhomme Richard, which rendered the ship inoperative.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and John Ismay
item.media:description: The U.S.S. Bonhomme Richard burned at Naval Base San Diego in July.

item.title: How Trump’s Convention Has Become a Crucial Play for the Suburbs
item.description: Conciliatory messages at the Republican convention were an acknowledgment by the president’s campaign that appealing to his right-wing base will not be enough to win re-election.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy W. Peters, Annie Karni and Nick Corasaniti
item.media:description: Voter opinions about President Trump have been remarkably impervious to the good and bad news about him, fluctuating little since he took office.

item.title: The Harsh Reality Behind Trump’s Reality Show
item.description: Night 2 of the R.N.C. took a more conciliatory tone, in contradiction to his actual policies.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello
item.media:description: President Trump took part in a naturalization ceremony at the White House that was aired on Tuesday during the convention.

item.title: Trump Takes Night Off From Anti-Immigrant Talk to Swear In U.S. Citizens
item.description: Five new American citizens were stunned to be naturalized at a White House ceremony during the Republican National Convention. Some said they did not know they were being broadcast until friends called to tell them.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: Salih Abdul Samad, center, and other new American citizens celebrating with their families after a naturalization ceremony at the White House on Tuesday.

item.title: Three Charged With Leaking Movies as Part of Global Piracy Ring
item.description: U.S. officials said members of the Sparks Group, an elite piracy network, fraudulently obtained and distributed movies ahead of release dates.
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin
item.media:description: The U.S. Attorney’s Office in New York said Wednesday that an American and a British man had been arrested and that a third person, a Norwegian, was being sought.

item.title: Top U.S. Officials Told C.D.C. to Soften Coronavirus Testing Guidelines
item.description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention abruptly changed its recommendations, saying people without Covid-19 symptoms should not get tested.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Chris Creese for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nurses administered coronavirus tests at a drive-through site in Tulsa, Okla., last month.

item.title: Brother of Impeachment Witness Says His Firing Was a Whistle-Blower Reprisal
item.description: Yevgeny Vindman, Alexander S. Vindman’s brother, says he was fired in retaliation for his role in the impeachment inquiry and for raising ethics and legal concerns about the national security adviser.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.category: Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
item.media:description: Lt. Col. Yevgeny Vindman, the twin brother of Lt. Col. Alexander S. Vindman, who testified in the impeachment inquiry, repeatedly raised concerns about Robert C. O’Brien, the national security adviser.

item.title: Justice Dept. Executes Lezmond Mitchell, a Native American Man Convicted of Murder
item.description: It was the fourth time this summer the Trump administration has carried out the death penalty. The case had raised issues of tribal sovereignty.
item.dc:creator: Hailey Fuchs
item.media:description: The federal prison in Terre Haute, Ind., where Lezmond Mitchell was executed on Wednesday.

item.title: White House Dismisses Questions of Whether Convention Events Broke Anti-Corruption Law
item.description: The law is aimed at preventing public officials from using their power for partisan political activity.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: United States Office of Special Counsel
item.media:description: President Trump attended a naturalization ceremony performed at the White House and broadcast as part of the Republican National Convention.

item.title: Impeachment, once seen as the battle of a generation, has vanished from the political landscape.
item.description: Six months after President Trump’s Senate trial, what was once seen as the battle of a generation has essentially vanished from the political landscape, all but unmentioned at either party’s convention.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: The national conversation is now being dominated by issues that were barely on the radar screen when President Trump’s trial ended.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: New York City residents are preparing for a possible resurgence in the fall.
item.dc:creator: Lara Takenaga and Jonathan Wolfe

item.title: Intelligence Officials See No Foreign Effort to Undermine Mail-In Voting
item.description: Their assessment contradicted part of President Trump’s attacks on absentee voting.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.category: Office of the Director of National Intelligence
item.media:description: Sorting ballots for a primary in Renton, Wash., this month. President Trump has warned without evidence that mail-in voting makes fraud easier.

item.title: ‘2020 Can Go to Hell’: The Story Behind the Viral Fire Photo That Said It All
item.description: Pandemic, unemployment, wildfire — Lake Berryessa, Calif., has seen it all this year. A photo from town that evoked the trauma of 2020 sped across the internet. Here, though, it was real life.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chris Lacombe looked over the remains of his home, which was destroyed by the L.N.U. Lightning Complex, in Spanish Flat, Calif.

item.title: Anthony Martignetti (‘Anthony!’), Who Raced Home for Spaghetti, Dies at 63
item.description: He was a 12-year-old Italian immigrant when a classic TV commercial for Prince, the Boston pasta company, gave him a lasting identity.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:description: Anthony Martignetti was 12 when he appeared in a TV commercial playing a boy in Boston’s Little Italy hungry for a plate of spaghetti.

item.title: RNC What to Watch For: Two of Trump’s Most Faithful Allies Will Headline
item.description: Vice President Mike Pence and Kellyanne Conway, President Trump’s former campaign manager and longtime adviser, will speak during tonight’s convention.
item.dc:creator: Astead W. Herndon
item.media:credit: Travis Dove for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vice President Mike Pence will speak from Fort McHenry in Baltimore on Wednesday, the third night of the Republican convention.

item.title: Did President Trump Violate the Hatch Act at the R.N.C.?
item.description: The law, which prohibits federal employees from engaging in political activities while on the job, has rarely led to the firing of political appointees.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague
item.media:description: President Trump and Melania Trump, the first lady, leaving the White House Rose Garden after she gave a speech at the Republican National Convention on Tuesday.

item.title: After rolling back transgender protections, the Trump campaign is courting the L.G.B.T.Q. vote.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman
item.media:description: Richard Grenell, the gay former U.S. ambassador to Germany, is expected to speak at the Republican National Convention on Wednesday night.

item.title: TV ratings rise on G.O.P.’s second night.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Eric Trump, President Trump’s son, at Mellon Auditorium in Washington, D.C., on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. Flood Strategy Shifts to ‘Unavoidable’ Relocation of Entire Neighborhoods
item.description: Using tax dollars to move whole communities out of flood zones, an idea long dismissed as radical, is swiftly becoming policy, marking a new and more disruptive phase of climate change.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle
item.media:credit: Calla Kessler for The New York Times
item.media:description: An empty lot near Oakwood Beach on Staten Island, where flooded homes have been bought and demolished by the government.

item.title: Family of Fort Hood Soldier Found Dead Demands Congress Investigate
item.description: The police said there was no sign of foul play after they found a body, believed to be that of Sgt. Elder N. Fernandes, about 30 miles from the base in Central Texas.
item.dc:creator: Allyson Waller
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Christopher Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The death has brought renewed scrutiny of Fort Hood, a sprawling Army complex in Texas. Several soldiers stationed there, including Specialist Vanessa Guillen, have died this year.

item.title: Ted Cruz Didn’t Get an RNC Invite. He Still Has Plenty to Say
item.description: In 2016, the Texas senator addressed his fellow Republicans but declined to explicitly endorse Donald Trump. One close Senate race and many conciliatory public comments later, he is on the sidelines this year.
item.dc:creator: Matt Flegenheimer
item.media:credit: Erin Scott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Ted Cruz on Capitol Hill in March. Mr. Cruz was not asked to speak at this year’s Republican National Convention.

item.title: Flood and Sacrifice: How an Old Convent Could Help Save New Orleans
item.description: A group of nuns in New Orleans is offering up its flooded former convent site to help protect the city during future such disasters.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Teague
item.media:credit: Abdul Aziz for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Sisters of St. Joseph are using the ruins of their motherhouse, which was flooded during Hurricane Katrina, to create one of the country’s largest urban wetlands.

item.title: After Three Years of Attacking L.G.B.T.Q. Rights, Trump Suddenly Tries Outreach
item.description: L.G.B.T.Q. advocates say the president has tried to divide their coalition by targeting transgender people in policy rollbacks.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman
item.media:description: President Trump in Bedminster, N.J., in August. Mr. Trump’s advisers are suddenly talking about L.G.B.T.Q. people as they scramble to find new voter support.

item.title: Schools Reopening: Parents in New York City Are Stressed
item.description: Plus, new data on outbreaks at college campuses.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Adam Pasick
item.media:description: Students’ desks met distancing rules at a Brooklyn school. It is uncertain whether New York City schools will open on Sept. 10 as scheduled.

item.title: Sarah Turney Sought Justice on TikTok. Now Her Father Is Charged With Homicide.
item.description: Alissa Turney disappeared in 2001, when she was 17. Her younger sister, Sarah Turney, has been investigating the case on social media.
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin
item.media:description: Investigators initially thought Alissa Turney, seen here at 16, might have run away from home.

item.title: Border Officials Weighed Deploying Migrant ‘Heat Ray’ Ahead of Midterms
item.description: Even as the Republican convention tries to soften President Trump’s image, he has made it clear that the extreme immigration policies of his first four years will be central to his re-election pitch.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: A group of men who were deported from the United States arriving last month at a migrant shelter in Nogales, Mexico.

item.title: Ancestry Promises Holocaust Records Will Be Free
item.description: The U.S.C. Shoah Foundation has partnered with the genealogy giant, and an initial rollout faced a glitch. But some survivor families don’t want their histories public.
item.dc:creator: Adam Popescu
item.media:credit: Michelle Groskopf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Renee and Klara Firestone, mother and daughter, with family photos. Renee Firestone has shared her testimony with the Shoah Foundation and the two have been involved with the organization for decades.

item.title: President Trump used the White House as a game show set, our TV critic writes.
item.media:description: Footage of a naturalization ceremony conducted at the White House was used in the Republican convention’s Tuesday night broadcast.

item.title: Stephanie Bice won a G.O.P. runoff to challenge the only Democrat in Oklahoma’s congressional delegation.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:credit: Sarah Phipps/The Oklahoman, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Stephanie Bice, an Oklahoma state senator, entering her watch party to give a speech after winning a runoff election for a U.S. House seat on Tuesday.

item.title: Biden is selling hand sanitizer with his Covid-19 plan printed on it.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher

item.title: A Woman May Have Been Cured of H.I.V. Without Medical Treatment
item.description: In dozens of other patients who suppress the virus without drugs, it seems to have been cornered in parts of the genome where it cannot reproduce, scientists reported.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: A colored scanning electron micrograph of a human T-cell, blue and green, infected with H.I.V., yellow. Even among viruses, H.I.V. is particularly wily and difficult to eradicate, inserting itself into the human genome and tricking the cell’s machinery into making copies.

item.title: Naturalization ceremony provides a moment of cognitive dissonance with Trump’s immigration stance.
item.description: The willingness to use the trappings of presidential power during a campaign convention was a stunning departure from the past.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Neil Vigdor
item.media:description: President Trump participating in a naturalization ceremony at the White House on Tuesday evening during the Republican National Convention.

item.title: 11 Female Voices, From Age 13 to 110, on Why the Vote Matters
item.description: “Your right.” “A duty.” “A very sacred act.” A century after suffrage, women reflect on what it means to them.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Harlan, Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Nicole Rifkin

item.title: Republican women in Arizona could play a pivotal role in an unusual battleground.
item.description: Led by a firebrand loyalist, the state party has lurched to the right under President Trump. That has turned off some Republicans, and Arizona suddenly appears in play for Democrats.
item.dc:creator: Elaina Plott
item.media:description: Kelli Ward, the chairwoman of the Arizona Republican Party, is a Trump loyalist who resembles the kind of voter toward whom the party is devoting its resources.

item.title: Peaceful Marches and Armored Vehicles: Scenes From Kenosha Protests
item.description: Unrest in Kenosha, Wis., continued after the police shooting of Jacob Blake, a Black resident. Peaceful demonstrations earlier in the day gave way to chaos as law enforcement faced off with protesters.
item.dc:creator: Erik Ljung, Katie G. Nelson and McKenzie Marshall
item.media:description: Aftermath following unrest in Kenosha, Wis., after the police shooting of Jacob Blake, a Black resident.

item.title: Trump keeps bending and breaking presidential norms. It will be easier for his successors to do the same.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Martin
item.media:credit: Travis Dove for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Charlotte, N.C., a hotel lobby TV broadcast coverage of the Republican National Convention on Tuesday.

item.title: Here’s how to watch Night 3 of the Republican convention, and who’s speaking.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor and Maggie Haberman
item.media:description: Eric Trump’s speech was shown in the Rose Garden of the White House on Tuesday, before Melania Trump spoke from the garden itself.

item.title: Night 1 of the R.N.C. was filled with foreboding. Night 2 was about softening the portrait of Trump.
item.description: In an abrupt swerve from the dire tone of the convention’s first night, President Trump staged a grab-bag of gauzy events and personal testimonials aimed at female and minority voters. His program blurred the lines between campaigning and governing.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin
item.media:description: First Lady Melania Trump delivered her Convention speech from the Rose Garden of the White House on Tuesday.

item.title: Republican convention speakers tried to recast Trump as an inclusive leader.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer and Sydney Ember
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: “This is a fight for freedom versus oppression,” said Tiffany Trump, the president’s younger daughter on a night in which Republicans sought to portray President Trump as a protector.
